comments.commentBody: I'm curious about whether there is a way to tell if gambling behaviors (in my case stock trading and sports betting) will worsen over time.  My boyfriend was an avid sports bettor until he turned to the stock market and now he's up at 6:30 researching stocks and "playing" earnings reports.  I can tell that he's really emotionally involved in the ups and downs - I've also dabbled in day trading and am cold and stoic, win or lose, in comparison with him.  If the frequency stays as-is I don't see a problem, but I wonder if there are warning signs that will hint at future problems for either of us.

Sanity and fear are definitely going mano a mano in this political season...  I find cross-referencing generally irksome, but don't mind it if I 1) catch on quickly and 2) love the puzzle!  Which I did.  I wish I were going to the rally.  JPG, make some noise for me!

I always enjoy looking at images of the past and really enjoyed the old B&W's.
There were some wonderful moments captured.

www.51artstudio.com

Joao,  Sending much strength and all my admiration.  I've been mesmerized by your work for years, so the news, for this fan, was gutting.  I'm sure it's hard to imagine the future from your hospital bed,  but believe in every step.  You have a gift.  That will never change.   I lost most of my leg to cancer as a child,  and get a surprised look when I turn up with a flack and cane for an embed.  But I suppose it's a testament to life.  And you have plenty of that left.  Heal fast,  heal well. Courage.  M

The top tourist attraction is the vast Burrell Collection at Pollok County Park, which features thousands of art works form Scotland and abroad. The hip West End is sprinkled with cafés, pubs, and boutiques. In addition, the huge Barras Market offers unlimited shopping. If you dare, check out the ghostly hilltop cemetery, Necropolis.

http://trip2europe.com/tag/glasgow/

Cliff Lee is mortal. And not so young. Not worth emptying the bank account for him. If the Yankees sign him, the contract should be based heavily on performance incentives. Not another A.J. Burnett give-away. But of course paying a fortune is the only way the Yankees can get him.

Brian Cashman needs to take off his pitching cap for a while and focus on the hitting drought and the infield problem. The infield problem is age -- mainly Jeter and Posada, with A-Rod not far behind. Texeira's batting slumps are a shame, but it is sure nice to have a real first baseman. Need to bring along Pena and Nunez. Pena seems to be a great infielder but needs to develop his batting skills. Cano is the supernova.

But the overall reason for the Yankees' loss in the ALCS was the same problem that plagued them throughout the year. It wasn't pitching. The team's failure this year was at the plate. Both Jeter and A-Rod have repeatedly said the key is starting pitching. Baloney. Gets them off the hook. This year's team was listless and lazy. Too much passivity. What happened between last year and this year? Aside from losing Matsui and Damon.

How much of the problem is a lack of desire on the part of the veterans? Sure, they would like to win another World Series. But are they really able to summon the energy and focus? Do they not feel like they have a stake in winning? The chemistry is not there and, more than anyone else, it's Girardi's job to fix that.

What all this statistical analysis can't take into account is....

... The HAIR !!

Lincecum's wild mane, and Wilson's thick beard will see them through anything.

As others mentioned, it took a while to settle a young rotation, purge Wellemeyer and then Zito, and it took several months to build the bullpen, one of the things Bochy is supposed to do well. He did go through many spare parts, discarding Runzler, Ray, Mota, Bautista, before setting on the current format and pecking order. Early in the season, this pen was awful.

For about 55 games now, the Giants have allowed 2 runs a game on average. It is also noted that the G won two more games in the regular season than the Rangers. Cain has been moved up one spot so he can pitch at home twice, where his flyballs will find Torres (a great defender) a lot. And Sanchez and Lincecum, the two strikeout artists, will pitch in Texas.

I am more worried about Bengie giving useful pointers to his teammates than about the Rangers. They have a meager bullpen, and average back of the rotation. The hitters have big home/road splits (Hamilton is 1200 at home. 900 on the road!), the Giants have a better RS/RA. I don't see this Texas dominance.
Finally.

Great way to start the day! Thoroughly enjoyable!
Typical lawyer, though -- it took longer to read his expanatory notes than it did to do the puzzle.

People keep saying, "Good pitching beats good hitting."

But the full quote is, "Good pitching beats good hitting . . . and visa versa."

The Giants beat H and 2 and O to win the pennant. Remember them? The best starting rotation in the universe? They're back home raking leaves right now.

It will take the entire staff to shut down the Rangers, and it will take the entire staff of the Rangers to bring down the Giants.

Whose got the better staff?

Toni,
Great round-up of reports on Favre and the Vikings -- thank you! My opinions....

1) Like others here, I also think it was odd --- and "flustery" --- of Coach Chilly to throw Favre under the bus after the game (and again today). Pot, meet kettle. Brett played an uneven game but so did Childress coach a pretty uneven game. I was shocked that he (and/or the boys upstairs) didn't red-flag that Andrew Quarless TD that the Packers scored. His whole body landed beyond the live area of the endzone! Also, what was the point of giving up at the end of the 1st half? A Peterson run had the Vikings up around the 35-yard-line with 25 seconds left. What's the harm in heaving a bomb to that big WR he just brought in (Moss) or to Harvin or to Berrian? A catch, an interference call -- there was a chance to get into field goal range. Why give up? Yes, Favre got outsmarted by the Packers' D, but Childress got out-coached by McCarthy (who, with all due respect, isn't known as one of the NFL's keenest coaching minds).

2) Before Childress jumps off a bridge over the loss, consider that this matchup was no gimme. The Packers were in a must-win mode, and the game was in Green Bay, and there was a big "get-even" motivation after getting swept by Minnesota last year. Yet the Vikings were in position to win at the end of the 4th quarter. It didn't work out, but that's no reason to start pushing panic buttons. The Vikes are one game behind the Packers and the Bears in the loss column.

3) Kudos to the patchwork Packer defense, which had Favre looking more indecisive than what we're accustomed to. Gunslingers usually don't hesitate, but Brett had several moments where he didn't find the right receiver. That happens. It doesn't mean he should be drawn and quartered, or lynched, or even benched.

4) I have a hard time understanding why Favre detractors are so full of venom. Man -- they talk like he's a despicable excuse for a human being --- an Adolf Hitler in football pads or something. Lighten up --- he's a football player who leaves it all on the field, and his 20-year career has provided tons of fun on the way to 500-plus TD passes, 70,000 yards, and 180-plus wins. I like what Bradley said in #6 above: Favre's play is "addictive," even now. The game last night was real theater, with ups and downs all night long --- even within the last 45 seconds, when Vikings fans went from the elation of a game-winning TD to the extreme letdown of an overturned call.

5) Given that Brett has two fractures in his ankle, I doubt we'll see him suit up next week (just my luck, living up here in New England!). With Favre, you never know for sure, but it seems like he'd need a miracle cure to play again even in two or three weeks, never mind in New England on Sunday. It's ironic that the franchise he led for 16 years is the one that appears to have ended his streak, don't you think?

Had a great fall weekend at the cedar crest last week.  The home is beautiful and the location is perfect to see everything.  Stayed in the Carirage house, very cool a 100+ year old house.  Also, used the 2 day passes they sell for the biltmore house. Dinner in the bilmore village is only 3 block away, try the corner kitchen.

As for post no. 19, such ignorance.

This is pure "Mangenius" football that we saw in 2006 with the Jets.  Trickery and deception can win games against superior opponents and give hope to fans of a perennial underdog but ultimately it will not take your football team where you want them to go and the rest of the league will figure it out.  Unfortunately for the Jets Brian Schottenheimer still has a bit of this condition left over from his time with Mangini where he tries to trick the opposition so much that the winds up outsmarting himself.  I doubt Mike Holmgren is fooled.  Unless the Browns can consistently line up and beat teams without trickery then Eric Mangini's career as an NFL head coach is about to come to a close.  Should Mangini wish to remain a head coach somewhere in the collegiate ranks (not a defensive assistant in the NFL) then he may entertain us further.

This is sweet revenge for NY against the state of Texas. The Rangers have the state flag on heir sleeve, the Cowboys the star. Ugh!  It's so great to see Jerry Jones miserable. He owns everything but what he wants most ain't happening. The Cowboys have no soul, while the Giants have regained their pride and swagger through hard work. Go Gmen. Just stop turning it over please Eli!
